RANITIDINE

H2-RECEPTOR ANTAGONISTS

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Unlicensed use
  • Exceptions to legal category
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Benign gastric ulceration, Duodenal ulceration,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg twice daily, alternatively 300 mg once daily, at night.
  • For children 1–5 months
    1 mg/kg 3 times a day (max. per dose 3 mg/kg 3 times a day).
  • For children 6 months–2 years
    2–4 mg/kg twice daily.
  • For children 3–11 years
    2–4 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 150 mg).
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg twice daily, alternatively 300 mg once daily, at night.

Chronic episodic dyspepsia,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg twice daily for 6 weeks, alternatively 300 mg once daily for 6 weeks, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg twice daily for 6 weeks, alternatively 300 mg once daily for 6 weeks, dose to be taken at night.

NSAID-associated gastric ulceration,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg twice daily for up to 8 weeks, alternatively 300 mg once daily for up to 8 weeks, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg twice daily for up to 8 weeks, alternatively 300 mg once daily for up to 8 weeks, dose to be taken at night.

NSAID-associated duodenal ulcer,

By mouth

  • For adults
    300 mg twice daily for 4 weeks, to achieve a higher healing rate.
  • For children 12–17 years
    300 mg twice daily for 4 weeks, to achieve a higher healing rate.

Prophylaxis of NSAID-associated gastric ulcer, Prophylaxis of NSAID-associated duodenal ulcer,

By mouth

  • For adults
    300 mg twice daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    300 mg twice daily.

Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg twice daily for up to 8 weeks or if necessary 12 weeks, alternatively 300 mg once daily for up to 8 weeks or if necessary 12 weeks, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg twice daily for up to 8 weeks or if necessary 12 weeks, alternatively 300 mg once daily for up to 8 weeks or if necessary 12 weeks, dose to be taken at night.

Moderate to severe gastro-oesophageal reflux disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    600 mg daily in 2–4 divided doses for up to 12 weeks.
  • For children 12–17 years
    600 mg daily in 2–4 divided doses for up to 12 weeks.

Long-term treatment of healed gastro-oesophageal reflux disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg twice daily.
  • For children 3–11 years
    2.5–5 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 300 mg).
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg twice daily.

Gastric acid reduction (prophylaxis of acid aspiration) in obstetrics,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg, dose to be given at onset of labour, then 150 mg every 6 hours.
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg, dose to be given at onset of labour, then 150 mg every 6 hours.

Gastric acid reduction (prophylaxis of acid aspiration) in surgical procedures,

Initially by intramuscular injection or by slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    50 mg, to be given 45–60 minutes before induction of anaesthesia, intravenous injection diluted to 20 mL and given over at least 2 minutes, alternatively (by mouth) 150 mg, to be given 2 hours before induction of anaesthesia and also when possible on the preceding evening.

Prophylaxis of stress ulceration,

Initially by slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    50 mg every 8 hours, dose to be diluted to 20 mL and given over at least 2 minutes, then (by mouth) 150 mg twice daily, may be given when oral feeding commences.

Reflux oesophagitis and other conditions where gastric acid reduction is beneficial,

By mouth

  • For children 1–5 months
    1 mg/kg 3 times a day (max. per dose 3 mg/kg 3 times a day).
  • For children 6 months–2 years
    2–4 mg/kg twice daily.
  • For children 3–11 years
    2–4 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 150 mg); increased to up to 5 mg/kg twice daily (max. per dose 300 mg), dose increase for severe gastro-oesophageal disease.
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg twice daily, alternatively 300 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night, then increased if necessary to 300 mg twice daily for up to 12 weeks in moderate to severe gastro-oesophageal reflux disease, alternatively increased if necessary to 150 mg 4 times a day for up to 12 weeks in moderate to severe gastro-oesophageal reflux disease.

Conditions where reduction of gastric acidity is beneficial and oral route not available,

By slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    50 mg every 6–8 hours.
  • For adults
    50 mg, dose to be diluted to 20 mL and given over at least 2 minutes; may be repeated every 6–8 hours.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid unless essential, but not known to be harmful.

Advice regarding renal impairment

In adults

Use half normal dose if eGFR less than 50 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

In children

Use half normal dose if estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 50 mL/minute/1.73 m 2.

Known side effects

General side effects

uncommon: Blurred vision,

notKnown: Alopecia, interstitial nephritis, involuntary movement disorders, pancreatitis,

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

For slow intravenous injection dilute to a concentration of 2.5 mg/mL with Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%; give over at least 3 minutes.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (Zantac ), give intermittently in Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

Advice for patients and carers

In fat malabsorption syndrome, give oral doses 1–2 hours before food to enhance effects of pancreatic enzyme replacement.

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Ranitidine for acid reflux

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/ranitidine-for-acid-reflux

Unlicensed use

With oral use in children

Oral preparations not licensed for use in children under 3 years.

With intravenous use in children

Injection not licensed for use in children under 6 months.

In adults

Doses given for prophylaxis of NSAID-associated gastric or duodenal ulcer, and prophylaxis of stress ulceration, are not licensed.

Exceptions to legal category

Ranitidine can be sold to the public for adults and children over 16 years (provided packs do not contain more than 2 weeks’ supply) for the short-term symptomatic relief of heartburn, dyspepsia, and hyperacidity, and for the prevention of these symptoms when associated with consumption of food or drink (max. single dose 75 mg, max. daily dose 300 mg).

Prepared medicinal forms of RANITIDINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution, infusion,
Tablet
Effervescent tablet
Oral solution
Solution for injection
